document.title: English Language Arts and Reading, Grade 7, Adopted 2017

6A24BC5C64A145DA867CCD3F1780D176.description: use an appropriate mode of delivery, whether written, oral, or multimodal, to present results.

40B4FE6856C9451FB9C5C92B725C9B98.description: display academic citations and use source materials ethically; and

89D9486B7F0B42149C4BCE52F9C36EE7.description: faulty reasoning such as hyperbole, emotional appeals, and stereotype;

E67E53B37B7C4BAAA8529CC145D4EEC8.description: differentiate between paraphrasing and plagiarism when using source materials;

69D90A97D2C140498F9E6D3585C71D5B.description: synthesize information from a variety of sources;

F22A885C840E4677A430E61EF953FC49.description: differentiate between primary and secondary sources;

3FE60AE5CE7E4ED2A9146F8C69AA6BD1.description: identify and gather relevant information from a variety of sources;

B33282020CB04CAC9D8C0E1353EB7A92.description: refine the major research question, if necessary, guided by the answers to a secondary set of questions;

6C18151FED6947EF9AA6F8C0145B914E.description: generate student-selected and teacher-guided questions for formal and informal inquiry;

1D631C69682B41EA8B6D293BEC28FEE4.description: Inquiry and research: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student engages in both short-term and sustained recursive inquiry processes for a variety of purposes. The student is expected to:

C7320667C2DB4698A713DDF6D666F38F.description: compose correspondence that reflects an opinion, registers a complaint, or requests information in a business or friendly structure.

B16EBDA5A0C641219CECD4D0C22A9C38.description: compose multi-paragraph argumentative texts using genre characteristics and craft; and

E1F75993C29543B0859CBD8C5BD8B65D.description: compose informational texts, including multi-paragraph essays that convey information about a topic, using a clear controlling idea or thesis statement and genre characteristics and craft;

68253D7FF24B4C21AB1F156E9192FEC5.description: compose literary texts such as personal narratives, fiction, and poetry using genre characteristics and craft;

821E9E719ABD40598B234A6A1A09E4FC.description: Composition: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--genres. The student uses genre characteristics and craft to compose multiple texts that are meaningful. The student is expected to:

5AD1CD61D3F44374B5ED7613AC81E854.description: publish written work for appropriate audiences.

AAC244E257AD4BE0826DFB7E64FBE76D.description: correct spelling, including commonly confused terms such as its/it's, affect/effect, there/their/they're, and to/two/too; and

0E749FF5056B47C18C96604D01CE6B4A.description: punctuation, including commas to set off words, phrases, and clauses, and semicolons; and

D421CDA4C87E4F87ACE1D6BB7911F93A.description: subordinating conjunctions to form complex sentences and correlative conjunctions such as either/or and neither/nor ;

EB26F00AC012408280D62527A78421CE.description: prepositions and prepositional phrases and their influence on subject-verb agreement;

37557A1E2FA144269EC8A181362A5241.description: consistent, appropriate use of verb tenses;

17B92A7F9D93403EA679E31CF8B5BB0E.description: complete complex sentences with subject-verb agreement and avoidance of splices, run-ons, and fragments ;

4C1DAE5023494A6ABE59B0A65D77F887.description: edit drafts using standard English conventions, including:

059BB321B5FB4B819C5A98D4EB83C37C.description: revise drafts for clarity, development, organization, style, word choice, and sentence variety;

2F284CDD666E44AEA48BD22068610893.description: developing an engaging idea reflecting depth of thought with specific facts, details, and examples;

FF0B4AC5E6194A96B4B833D085B5577E.description: organizing with purposeful structure, including an introduction, transitions, coherence within and across paragraphs, and a conclusion; and

0FB922351C2343CA91277CF0CBF8F823.description: develop drafts into a focused, structured, and coherent piece of writing by:

50FB81706AA648D38596FCE0877865C1.description: plan a first draft by selecting a genre appropriate for a particular topic, purpose, and audience using a range of strategies such as discussion, background reading, and personal interests;

D39902E989C445EB8F6E217BC11442F5.description: Composition: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--writing process. The student uses the writing process recursively to compose multiple texts that are legible and uses appropriate conventions. The student is expected to:

A08F9F6C1A6F431C8935DD7DE32E945E.description: explain the purpose of rhetorical devices such as direct address and rhetorical questions and logical fallacies such as loaded language and sweeping generalizations.

27A811F8F83647728A1FE7A8E5FA2F7B.description: analyze how the author's use of language contributes to mood, voice, and tone; and

44F63974B90740AB853647732EC48C3C.description: identify the use of literary devices, including subjective and objective point of view;

EA29C2483AB74BA080C375093CCEEE56.description: describe how the author's use of figurative language such as metaphor and personification achieves specific purposes;

BDED7C32EDCD40349024BCC732F7EC74.description: analyze the author's use of print and graphic features to achieve specific purposes;

77572DE9DE9C43138C7445E76DC0E4DA.description: analyze how the use of text structure contributes to the author's purpose;

5D46052918EA4F4093B183BF42771402.description: explain the author's purpose and message within a text;

2E91EDED6C684FFFA85D86A6463110BD.description: Author's purpose and craft: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student uses critical inquiry to analyze the authors' choices and how they influence and communicate meaning within a variety of texts. The student analyzes and applies author's craft purposefully in order to develop his or her own products and performances. The student is expected to:

3610FEE3F6554C71AB965B64FAFB2F6F.description: analyze characteristics of multimodal and digital texts.

39A9A81FFCD54E2D958761CCF89963D4.description: identifying the intended audience or reader; and

D8318AEE131549B1B77CFA1A42A2CB26.description: explaining how the author uses various types of evidence and consideration of alternatives to support the argument; and

C268A9D425304E46A43A3B4CCE85B94C.description: analyze characteristics and structures of argumentative text by:

EAC4C97BBECA4D6286B315EC41D727DF.description: organizational patterns that support multiple topics, categories, and subcategories;

4939F26D4E9C4A25BFD4FA9A2107E4DB.description: features such as references or acknowledgements; and

F15A8046C60D44E4BDF5FCEF89489A06.description: the controlling idea or thesis with supporting evidence;

2E6FDE0241BB4DE38F3ED017EC8732C5.description: analyze characteristics and structural elements of informational text, including:

8BE28A318D084BC8A7F1DBFCD081BD0A.description: analyze how playwrights develop characters through dialogue and staging;

AEFBDEE5EE47485D9BC5C9CD130A5F5B.description: analyze the effect of rhyme scheme, meter, and graphical elements such as punctuation and capitalization in poems across a variety of poetic forms;

C7FBF457F94B440F961EE361E1218455.description: demonstrate knowledge of literary genres such as realistic fiction, adventure stories, historical fiction, mysteries, humor, myths, fantasy, and science fiction;

437F7BA9107F478B97F694FC6E939E8E.description: Multiple genres: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--genres. The student recognizes and analyzes genre-specific characteristics, structures, and purposes within and across increasingly complex traditional, contemporary, classical, and diverse texts. The student is expected to:

8E5465A5CEC0446C8B496A493FB8C2D3.description: analyze how the setting influences character and plot development.

F11EE2B0E12849C99250E262E25C0907.description: analyze plot elements, including the use of foreshadowing and suspense, to advance the plot; and

FC6205C3F18E4D26A2B599842EA6FB12.description: analyze how characters' qualities influence events and resolution of the conflict;

2E34AB8A9C4E4347AFD3EDC7C6821946.description: infer multiple themes within and across texts using text evidence;

B41BBC22482649ACA7CE4D624721D34F.description: Multiple genres: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts--literary elements. The student recognizes and analyzes literary elements within and across increasingly complex traditional, contemporary, classical, and diverse literary texts. The student is expected to:

9050853473494E6E9DE45E5446726587.description: reflect on and adjust responses as new evidence is presented.

D5879B899760443CA56B1CD5DE42B3C3.description: respond orally or in writing with appropriate register, vocabulary, tone, and voice; and

7FBF4DCC15A648C9BFDC4C6F4B04992A.description: discuss and write about the explicit or implicit meanings of text;

535F4013976244F884AB5E25309533C3.description: respond using newly acquired vocabulary as appropriate;

6EC7BA74A560425AA31EDD1EA4BB762B.description: interact with sources in meaningful ways such as notetaking, annotating, freewriting, or illustrating;

FEA72E5CC5EB46669B7C1919F6BC847B.description: paraphrase and summarize texts in ways that maintain meaning and logical order;

9EE823E0888546E491E1808B6543207C.description: use text evidence to support an appropriate response;

B5CC02F2A5D74A68A9A58CE58E4D588E.description: write responses that demonstrate understanding of texts, including comparing sources within and across genres;

B6EB48F9511D43DC82EBC83E4270BF65.description: describe personal connections to a variety of sources, including self-selected texts;

FB3E5535C0414837B2D064A7F853D392.description: Response skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student responds to an increasingly challenging variety of sources that are read, heard, or viewed. The student is expected to:

6E373956620B46A886F6F74534416F30.description: monitor comprehension and make adjustments such as re-reading, using background knowledge, asking questions, and annotating when understanding breaks down.

2CD84371E372490BA0D4FFD68A82956D.description: synthesize information to create new understanding; and

DFF35DBB626043209903C724388B414C.description: evaluate details read to determine key ideas;

A35CA962864E4EA89DEE7E7A6D45046C.description: make inferences and use evidence to support understanding;

521D3C90CC39414FAC1C5DF8E95D3CA9.description: make connections to personal experiences, ideas in other texts, and society;

B4A22195A8504D05BEB35322DFA5AE80.description: create mental images to deepen understanding;

4DB11EE29E1D41659A254FEFDE4D3958.description: make and correct or confirm predictions using text features, characteristics of genre, and structures;

91BCE449254349DB864DE96F0DE7AD8A.description: generate questions about text before, during, and after reading to deepen understanding and gain information;

C55567CFC1FE4617A19410FE7BEBB0E4.description: establish purpose for reading assigned and self-selected texts;

6C9DB7035D3C414F8442687124935066.description: Comprehension skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking using multiple texts. The student uses metacognitive skills to both develop and deepen comprehension of increasingly complex texts. The student is expected to:

A0F0F83734424CBBAEB38EC8C5CF76EF.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking--self-sustained reading. The student reads grade-appropriate texts independently. The student is expected to self-select text and read independently for a sustained period of time.

4BF7C77A491840B8A3F51737099B8C8E.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking--fluency. The student reads grade-level text with fluency and comprehension. The student is expected to adjust fluency when reading grade-level text based on the reading purpose.

D6FDFED98C9547ED9D47C7FF90169B3A.description: determine the meaning and usage of grade-level academic English words derived from Greek and Latin roots such as omni, log/logue, gen, vid/vis, phil, luc, and sens/sent.

3CB21C625CA0439AA94BD0CF5F86A77F.description: use context such as contrast or cause and effect to clarify the meaning of words; and

64F0BEF4F9BE40028B5CCA65299EF8EE.description: use print or digital resources to determine the meaning, syllabication, pronunciation, word origin, and part of speech;

208F60BDCC7D4AEE96B53630F3EBF261.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking--vocabulary. The student uses newly acquired vocabulary expressively. The student is expected to:

547D5A81115A4647B1AD55786CA72142.description: engage in meaningful discourse and provide and accept constructive feedback from others.

C057AA50095E49AEBF391F9197247B14.description: present a critique of a literary work, film, or dramatic production, employing eye contact, speaking rate, volume, enunciation, a variety of natural gestures, and conventions of language to communicate ideas effectively; and

C6D1DF0FDAA6405DA8399A4334C4AC88.description: follow and give complex oral instructions to perform specific tasks, answer questions, or solve problems;

24C06E0700F6430DACDFB118FE299A88.description: listen actively to interpret a message and ask clarifying questions that build on others' ideas;

BB45098021464774900ABAB9D9A82CF9.description: Developing and sustaining foundational language skills: listening, speaking, discussion, and thinking--oral language. The student develops oral language through listening, speaking, and discussion. The student is expected to:

8C78579532F24BA883D255DA5B64F8BC.description: Statements that contain the word "including" reference content that must be mastered, while those containing the phrase "such as" are intended as possible illustrative examples.

4283D7CCF6604FEBA1EBA68B2EA02899.description: Oral language proficiency holds a pivotal role in school success; verbal engagement must be maximized across grade levels (Kinsella, 2010). In order for students to become thinkers and proficient speakers in science, social studies, mathematics, fine arts, language arts and reading, and career and technical education, they must have multiple opportunities to practice and apply the academic language of each discipline (Fisher, Frey, & Rothenberg, 2008).

C3D12B6C3FE145C089E36692A46AC5FE.description: Current research stresses the importance of effectively integrating second language acquisition with quality content area education in order to ensure that ELLs acquire social and academic language proficiency in English, learn the knowledge and skills, and reach their full academic potential. Instruction must be linguistically accommodated in accordance with the English Language Proficiency Standards (ELPS) and the student's English language proficiency levels to ensure the mastery of knowledge and skills in the required curriculum is accessible. For a further understanding of second language acquisition needs, refer to the ELPS and proficiency-level descriptors adopted in Chapter 74, Subchapter A, of this title (relating to Required Curriculum).

E848039A934E4398871F5073A18B9416.description: English language learners (ELLs) are expected to meet standards in a second language; however, their proficiency in English influences the ability to meet these standards. To demonstrate this knowledge throughout the stages of English language acquisition, comprehension of text requires additional scaffolds such as adapted text, translations, native language support, cognates, summaries, pictures, realia, glossaries, bilingual dictionaries, thesauri, and other modes of comprehensible input. ELLs can and should be encouraged to use knowledge of their first language to enhance vocabulary development; vocabulary needs to be in the context of connected discourse so that it is meaningful. Strategic use of the student's first language is important to ensure linguistic, affective, cognitive, and academic development in English.

F1634CC239D74AB78CCA183CBA3159D8.description: Text complexity increases with challenging vocabulary, sophisticated sentence structures, nuanced text features, cognitively demanding content, and subtle relationships among ideas (Texas Education Agency, STAAR Performance Level Descriptors, 2013). As skills and knowledge are obtained in each of the seven strands, students will continue to apply earlier standards with greater depth to increasingly complex texts in multiple genres as they become self-directed, critical learners who work collaboratively while continuously using metacognitive skills.

6100CB6457364013ABE7CD8C6107BB8A.description: The seven strands of the essential knowledge and skills for English language arts and reading are intended to be integrated for instructional purposes and are recursive in nature. Strands include the four domains of language (listening, speaking, reading, writing) and their application in order to accelerate the acquisition of language skills so that students develop high levels of social and academic language proficiency. Although some strands may require more instructional time, each strand is of equal value, may be presented in any order, and should be integrated throughout the year. Additionally, students should engage in academic conversations, write, read, and be read to on a daily basis with opportunities for cross-curricular content and student choice.

6C879225998F48A986C4353FA49D0314.description: The English language arts and reading Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKS) embody the interconnected nature of listening, speaking, reading, writing, and thinking through the seven integrated strands of developing and sustaining foundational language skills; comprehension; response; multiple genres; author's purpose and craft; composition; and inquiry and research. The strands focus on academic oracy (proficiency in oral expression and comprehension), authentic reading, and reflective writing to ensure a literate Texas. The strands are integrated and progressive with students continuing to develop knowledge and skills with increased complexity and nuance in order to think critically and adapt to the ever-evolving nature of language and literacy.
